text: Publisher's Introduction. Praise be to Allah who said: {Indeed, We have sent it down as an Arabic Qur'an}, and peace and blessings be upon the one who was given the comprehensive words, who taught his companions to read the Quran fresh and tender. To proceed: The Proof, the Scholar Imam Ibn Malik al-Andalusi al-Jayyani wrote his Alfiyah, which became the destination for students, and was explained by many knowing scholars, and was also summarized. Imam al-Suyuti, may Allah have mercy on him, was a man of high ambition and the renewer of his era; he mastered arts and sciences and loved to have a share in that. Thus, he summarized Ibn Malik's Alfiyah into (635) verses. Surprisingly, Egypt was devoid of a copy of this summary of the Alfiyah; indeed, the entire world was devoid of it as far as we know, except for Andalusia (Spain). Allah preserved this summary for us in the Escorial Library in Spain. It is a precious copy written by his noble student, the scholar Imam Muhammad bin Ali al-Dawudi, author of Tabaqat al-Mufassirin. What a blessed copy, in the handwriting of a blessed Imam, for a blessed Imam, summarizing the Alfiyah of a blessed Imam. It was verified by a virtuous, blessed, occupied, achieving, and artistic brother, the virtuous brother Hamza Abu Toha, may Allah keep him safe, from the holy lands of Sham, Palestine. Praise be to Allah who honored us with publishing it. We ask Allah for benefit through it, sincerity, and acceptance; He is the Guardian of the answer, Glory be to Him. Written by the servant of the Islamic Nation's heritage, Abd al-Ati Muhyi al-Sharqawi Abu Yaqub al-Azhari.

text: Introduction. The science of grammar has had a plentiful share of scientific poems. Some of them collected most chapters of grammar, such as Alfiyat Ibn Mu'ti, Alfiyat Ibn Malik, Alfiyat al-Athari, and Alfiyat al-Suyuti, and before them Mulhat al-I'rab. Others specialized in singular issues, such as al-Qasidah al-Majradiyah, Al-Muradi's poem on sentences, Al-Zawawi's poem on rules of parsing, and the Mimiyah poem by Hazim al-Qartajanni. Perhaps the first poem in grammar—as it is said—is the poem of Al-Khalil bin Ahmad al-Farahidi, though the scholar Dr. Al-Tanahi questioned this attribution to Al-Khalil bin Ahmad and preferred that the first era of poems was after the fourth century (1). The most famous of these poems are Mulhat al-I'rab by Al-Hariri, Alfiyat Ibn Mu'ti, Al-Wafiyah by Ibn al-Hajib, Alfiyat Ibn Malik, and Alfiyat al-Suyuti called Al-Faridah. Alfiyat Ibn Malik is the most famous absolutely; if the word 'Alfiyah' is used, it refers to it without ambiguity. Since Alfiyat Ibn Malik is the most useful of grammar poems, major scholars dedicated themselves to explaining it, teaching it in their circles, and writing comments, restrictions, footnotes, and explanations for the evidences in its explanations, and some summarized it. Among the most important of these summaries is "Al-Wafiyah bi-Ikhtisar al-Alfiyah" by Imam Jalal al-Din al-Suyuti. The resolve was set to dedicate oneself to this summary for verification and study, due to the benefit it holds for students, in the form of summarizing the grammatical benefit with fewer words while preserving the rule, or perhaps adding a benefit over the Alfiyah. And Allah is the Granter of success. Hamza Mustafa Hasan Abu Toha 23/7/2018.

text: Biography of Imam Ibn Malik (1). He is Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Abdullah bin Malik, the unique scholar, Jamal al-Din, Abu Abdullah al-Ta'i, al-Jayyani, al-Shafi'i, the Grammarian. He became famous as "Ibn Malik," attributed to his great-grandfather, and his Kunya was Abu Abdullah. He is famous beyond description, so we need not elaborate on his biography. There is a difference regarding his year of birth; Al-Hawari and Ibn Qadi Shuhbah believed he was born in the year 598 AH. Ibn Shakir, Ibn Kathir, Al-Firuzabadi, and Al-Suyuti believed he was born in the year 600 AH. Al-Safadi believed he was born in the year 601 AH. The most correct view is that he was born in 598 AH, based on what his contemporary Kamal al-Din bin al-Adim said, that Ibn Malik told him so. Ibn Malik was born in the city of Jaen in Andalusia, received knowledge there, then traveled to the lands of the East, then Egypt, and finally settled in Damascus, where he died in the middle of the year 672 AH. Many people studied under Ibn Malik, including: 1. Muhammad bin Abd al-Rahman bin Muhammad bin Abd al-Rahman al-Sulami al-Dimashqi al-Hanafi, Badr al-Din, known as Ibn al-Fuwaira (d. 672). 2. Muhammad bin Abd al-Qawi bin Badran al-Mardawi al-Jama'ili al-Hanbali, Abu Abdullah, Shams al-Din (d. 699 AH). 3. Muhammad bin Abd al-Rahman bin Yusuf bin Muhammad al-Ba'labkki al-Hanbali, Abu Abdullah, Shams al-Din (d. 699 AH).
foot_note: 1. See: Al-Wafi bil-Wafiyat 3/285, Tabaqat al-Shafi'iyyah al-Kubra 8/67, Bughyat al-Wu'at 1/130, Nafh al-Tib 2/228, and Alfiyat Ibn Malik 11.

Muhammad bin Isma'il bin Ibrahim al-Dimashqi al-Ansari al-Abbadi, Abu Abdullah, known as Ibn al-Khabbaz (d. 756 AH). Ibn Malik had three children, the most famous being his son Badr al-Din Abu Abdullah, his eldest son, who died in 686 AH; his son Taqi al-Din, nicknamed 'The Lion' (Al-Asad), for whom Ibn Malik wrote 'Al-Muqaddimah Al-Asadiyah', who died in 699 AH; and his son Shams al-Din, who died in 719 AH. Among Ibn Malik's works are 'Al-Mu'assal fi Nazm al-Mufassal', which he then dissolved and called 'Sabk al-Manzum wa Fakk al-Makhtum'—and whoever says its name is 'Fakk al-Manzum wa Sabk al-Makhtum' has contradicted transmission and reason. Among Ibn Malik's books are 'Al-Kafiyah Al-Shafiyah' (three thousand verses) and its explanation; 'Al-Khulasah' which is the summary of Al-Kafiyah Al-Shafiyah; 'Ikmal al-I'lam bi-Muthallath al-Kalam', a large volume with many benefits indicating great knowledge; 'Lamiyat al-Af'al' and its explanation; 'Fa'ala wa Af'ala'; 'Al-Muqaddimah Al-Asadiyah' written in the name of his son Al-Asad;

As for language, he was the ultimate authority in citing its rarities and knowing its obscure terms. As for grammar and morphology, he was an ocean that could not be kept up with and a scholar that could not be rivaled. As for the Arabic poetry used as evidence for language and grammar, the leading Imams were bewildered by him and amazed at where he retrieved it from. Composing poetry was easy for him, whether Rajaz, Tawil, Basit, or others, along with his solid religion, truthful tongue, frequent voluntary prayers, good bearing, softness of heart, perfect intellect, dignity, and deliberation" (2). Ibn Kathir said: "He advanced and prevailed in the arts of grammar and recitations, achieving a great deal in them, and surpassing many who preceded him in this regard, along with religion, truthfulness, good bearing, frequent voluntary prayers, perfect intellect, dignity, and friendliness" (3).

text: Biography of Imam Al-Suyuti (1). His Name: Abd al-Rahman bin al-Kamal Abi Bakr bin Muhammad bin Sabiq al-Din bin al-Fakhr Uthman bin Nazir al-Din Muhammad bin Sayf al-Din Khidr bin Najm al-Din Abi al-Salah Ayyub bin Nasir al-Din Muhammad bin Sheikh Humam al-Din al-Humam al-Khudayri al-Asyuti. Al-Suyuti said: "As for my great-grandfather Humam al-Din, he was among the people of spiritual reality (Ahl al-Haqiqah). As for our attribution 'Al-Khudayri', I do not know what this refers to except Al-Khudayriyyah, a quarter in Baghdad. Someone I trust told me that he heard my father—may Allah have mercy on him—mention that his great-grandfather was a non-Arab or from the East, so it appears the attribution is to the mentioned quarter. I was born after Maghrib on the eve of Sunday, the beginning of Rajab in the year 849. I was carried during my father's life to Sheikh Muhammad al-Majdhub, a man who was among the major saints near the Nafisi Shrine, and he blessed me. I grew up an orphan, memorized the Quran while I was under eight years old, then memorized Al-Umdah, Minhaj al-Fiqh and al-Usul, and Alfiyat Ibn Malik. I began engaging in knowledge from the beginning of the year 64. I took Fiqh and Grammar from a group of Sheikhs. I took inheritance law (Fara'id) from the scholar, the inheritance expert of his time, Sheikh Shihab al-Din al-Sharmasahi, who was said to have reached a very old age, well over a hundred, and Allah knows best. I read to him his explanation of Al-Majmu', and I was granted a license to teach Arabic at the beginning of the year 66.
foot_note: 1. This biography is transferred from Al-Suyuti's biography of himself in Husn al-Muhadarah 1/335.

text: I authored in this year; the first thing I authored was [on] Isti'adha (Seeking Refuge) and Basmalah. I presented it to our Sheikh, Sheikh al-Islam Alam al-Din al-Bulqini, and he wrote a commendation for it. I stayed with him in Fiqh until he died, then I stayed with his son, reading to him from the beginning of 'Al-Tadrib' by his father up to Agency (Wakalah). I heard from him from the beginning of 'Al-Hawi Al-Saghir' to Number (Al-Adad), from the beginning of 'Al-Minhaj' to Zakat, from the beginning of 'Al-Tanbih' to near the chapter of Zakat, a piece of 'Al-Rawdah' from the chapter of Judiciary, a piece of 'Takmilat Sharh al-Minhaj' by Al-Zarkashi, and from Reviving Dead Land (Ihya' al-Mawat) to Wills or thereabouts. He licensed me to teach and issue fatwas from the year 76 and attended my inaugural lecture. When he died in the year 78, I stuck to Sheikh al-Islam Sharaf al-Din al-Manawi, reading a piece of 'Al-Minhaj' to him and hearing it from him regarding division, except for sessions I missed. I heard lessons from the explanation of 'Al-Bahjah' and a footnote on it, and from the Tafsir of Al-Baydawi. In Hadith and Arabic, I stuck to our Sheikh, the scholar Imam Taqi al-Din al-Shibli al-Hanafi; I attended him for four years. He wrote a commendation for me on the explanation of Alfiyat Ibn Malik and on 'Jam' al-Jawami' in Arabic, which I authored, and he testified more than once to my advancement in sciences with his tongue and pen. I stuck to our Sheikh, the scholar, the Teacher of Existence, Muhyi al-Din al-Kafiji for fourteen years, taking from him the arts of Exegesis (Tafsir), Principles (Usul), Arabic, Semantics (Ma'ani), and others, and he wrote me a great license. I attended numerous lessons with Sheikh Sayf al-Din al-Hanafi in 'Al-Kashhaf', 'Al-Tawdih' and its footnote, 'Talkhis al-Miftah', and 'Al-Adud'. I began classifying (writing books) in the year 66. I traveled, praise be to Allah, to the lands of Sham, Hijaz, Yemen, India, Morocco, and Takrur. When I performed Hajj, I drank Zamzam water for several matters, among them that I reach the rank of Sheikh Siraj al-Din al-Bulqini in Fiqh and the rank of Hafiz Ibn Hajar in Hadith.

text: I issued fatwas from the beginning of the year 71, and held dictation sessions for Hadith from the beginning of the year 72. I was blessed with deep knowledge in seven sciences: Exegesis, Hadith, Fiqh, Grammar, Semantics (Ma'ani), Rhetoric (Bayan), and Badi' (Metaphors/Style), according to the method of the Arabs and eloquent scholars, not the method of the Persians and philosophers. What I believe is that what I have reached in these seven sciences, other than Fiqh and the transmissions I have seen in them, none of my Sheikhs reached or stood upon, let alone those below them. As for Fiqh, I do not say that; rather, my Sheikh in it had a broader view and a longer reach. Below these seven in knowledge are: Principles of Jurisprudence (Usul al-Fiqh), Dialectics (Jadal), and Morphology (Tasrif). Below them are Composition (Insha'), Epistolography (Tawassul), and Inheritance (Fara'id). Below them are Recitations (Qira'at), which I did not take from a Sheikh. Below them is Medicine. As for the science of Arithmetic (Hisab), it is the hardest thing for me and the furthest from my mind; if I look into a problem related to it, it is as if I am trying to carry a mountain. The tools of Ijtihad have been completed for me now, praise be to Allah Almighty. I say this speaking of Allah's blessing, not out of pride; for what is there in this world that seeking to acquire it would be a source of pride, when departure is imminent, gray hair has appeared, and the best of life is gone! If I wished to write a book on every issue with its sayings, transmitted and analogical evidences, their contexts, refutations, answers, and weighing between the differences of schools of thought, I would be able to do that by Allah's grace, not by my power or strength. There is no power or strength except by Allah; what Allah wills happens; there is no strength except by Allah. In the early stages of seeking knowledge, I read something in the science of Logic, then Allah cast a hatred for it into my heart, and I heard that Ibn al-Salah issued a fatwa prohibiting it, so I left it for that reason, and Allah Almighty compensated me for it with the science of Hadith, which is the noblest of sciences.

text: The Book. Documentation and attribution of this book to Al-Suyuti is something no two people would differ on, nor two goats would butt heads over. This has been proven to me beyond doubt. I relied on several things for this, including: 1. Al-Suyuti mentioned it in his book 'Al-Tahadduth bi-Ni'mat Allah' among his works, saying: "Al-Wafiyah bi-Ikhtisar al-Alfiyah, six hundred verses" (1). 2. Al-Suyuti mentioned it in the index of his works saying: "Al-Wafiyah bi-Ikhtisar al-Alfiyah" (2). 3. Haji Khalifa said when mentioning the Alfiyah and Al-Suyuti's explanation of it: "He has a summary of the Alfiyah in six hundred and thirty lines, and he named it 'Al-Wafiyah'" (3). 4. This appears clearly in the introduction of the book, where Al-Suyuti said in the first verse: The hoper of the Exalted's mercy says... A servant of Rahman, the son of Al-Suyuti (4)

text: Definition of Alfiyat Ibn Malik. Imam Ibn Malik composed his Alfiyah in the city of Hama at the request of Imam Sharaf al-Din al-Barzi. Ibn al-Wardi said: "Our Sheikh, the Chief Judge Sharaf al-Din Hibatullah bin al-Barzi told me: Sheikh Jamal al-Din organized 'Al-Khulasah Al-Alfiyah' in Hama at our place for my study. I was a young man and served him, and I saw the blessing of my service to him" (1). This Alfiyah contains seventy-eight chapters and sections, containing most of the purposes of grammar, as Ibn Malik said at its conclusion: It included most of the important matters in verse (2). This Alfiyah is originally a summary of a large poem by Ibn Malik called "Al-Kafiyah Al-Shafiyah", the number of its verses being two thousand seven hundred and fifty-something. Ibn Malik said at the conclusion of Al-Kafiyah Al-Shafiyah (3): Its verses are two thousand and seven hundred... And fifty and something completed it. He mentioned in the Alfiyah that this Alfiyah is a summary of Al-Kafiyah Al-Shafiyah, saying: The Summary (Al-Khulasah) enumerated from Al-Kafiyah (4). Allah wrote fame and spread for this Alfiyah; riders traveled with it, people carried it everywhere, and major scholars gathered in its courtyards explaining and extracting its hidden gems.

2. See: Al-Alfiyah p. 188, verse 999. 
3. See: Sharh al-Kafiyah al-Shafiyah 4/2252. 
4. See: Al-Alfiyah p. 188, verse 1000.

text: Among the most important of these explanations are the explanation of Ibn al-Nazim, explanation of Abu Hayyan, explanation of Al-Muradi, explanation of Ibn Aqil, explanation of Ibn Hisham, explanation of Al-Shatibi, explanation of Al-Makudi, explanation of Al-Suyuti, and many other explanations. Some scholars summarized the Alfiyah, among them Muhammad bin Muhammad bin Ali bin Umar al-Isnawi, as well as Imam Ibn al-Wardi who summarized the Alfiyah in one hundred and fifty verses calling it 'Al-Tuhfah Al-Wardiyyah', then he explained this summary and it has been printed. Among them is a summary called 'Al-Mukhtasar al-Mufid' by Mahmud Mahfuz al-Dimashqi; a copy of it exists in Cairo (Than 2: 158). And among these summaries is this summary which we are verifying: 'Al-Wafiyah bi-Ikhtisar al-Alfiyah' by Imam Al-Suyuti.

text: Al-Wafiyah bi-Ikhtisar al-Alfiyah. The number of verses in Al-Wafiyah reached six hundred and thirty-five verses, which is approximately two-thirds the size of the Alfiyah. Al-Suyuti was truthful when he said in the conclusion of Al-Wafiyah (1): I organized it in about two-thirds of its original... And you will never see a summary like it. This does not contradict what Haji Khalifa said in Kashf al-Zunun, where he said: "He has a summary of the Alfiyah in six hundred and thirty lines, and he named it 'Al-Wafiyah'" (2), because this count is approximate, as is the custom of scholars in determining the number of verses in poems. A questioner might ask: What is the benefit of Al-Wafiyah? I say that in addition to being a summary of the Alfiyah that reduces the wording of the grammatical rule, it was in many places of added benefit. Look at Al-Suyuti's saying: And 'Ya' of the self with the verb follows... The Nun of protection, and in "Layta" connect it. And its deletion is anomalous, and the reverse of it is "La'alla"... In four (3) give choice, and Yahya (4) the connection was rare. Look at his saying: "and Yahya the connection was rare"; it is an addition to the wording of the Alfiyah. And his saying: And possessor of addition becomes a proper noun... If it prevails, or "Al" (5), and its deletion (6) requires. If you add or call out, I said the Lam in... "Allah" was not added and did not define. Look at him adding the disagreement regarding the Alif and Lam in the majestic word "Allah".
foot_note:
1. See verse 632. 
2. See: Kashf al-Zunun 1/152. 
3. He means the abrogating letters other than La'alla and Layta, which are: Inna, Anna, Lakinna, and Ka'anna. 
4. He refers to Imam Al-Farra, Abu Zakariya Yahya bin Ziyad. See his opinion in Sharh Al-Muradi 1/381. 
5. Meaning: And possessor of "Al" becomes a proper noun if it prevails. 
6. Meaning: deletion of Al.

text: When you return to the places of initiating with an indefinite noun, and to his saying: And "raghbatun fi al-khayri khayratun", and text... Of a ruling gives benefit, and that which is general and specific (1). You see him adding "and that which is general and specific". Among the characteristics of this summary is that—despite its small size—it did not neglect comparing Ibn Malik's words with his other books. He said: And similar to it in "Khiltanihi", "Kuntuhu"... text: Al-Suyuti's Relationship with Ibn Malik's Works. Al-Suyuti was aware of the value of Ibn Malik's works; he was among the scholars most attached to Ibn Malik's works. We mention among them: His book 'Al-Bahjah Al-Mardiyah' or 'Al-Nahjah Al-Mardiyah', in which he explained Alfiyat Ibn Malik with a mixed explanation (interwoven text), which is an intermediate explanation. His book 'Al-Nukat ala Al-Alfiyah wal-Kafiyah wal-Shafiyah wal-Shudhur wal-Nuzhah', where Al-Suyuti combined these books, edited the issues in them, cited objections to important parts, and discussed their authors. His book 'Ham' al-Hawami'', and if you ask what the relationship is, I say: One of the greatest grammar texts is 'Al-Tashil' by Ibn Malik, and the greatest explanation of Al-Tashil is Abu Hayyan's explanation called 'Al-Tadhyil wal-Takmil'. Abu Hayyan stripped this great explanation of the reasoning of its issues in a book called 'Irtishaf al-Darb'. The book 'Ham' al-Hawami'' kept Ibn Malik's Tashil and Irtishaf al-Darb in sight, as Al-Suyuti stated in the introduction of Al-Ham' saying: "Encompassing the summary of the books Al-Tashil and Al-Irtishaf" (1). Also, Al-Suyuti's book 'Al-Faridah', which is his Alfiyah in grammar; he summarized Ibn Malik's Alfiyah in it in about six hundred verses and added four hundred verses of his own.

text: Between Al-Faridah and Al-Wafiyah. Perhaps the first to open the door for organizing an Alfiyah (thousand-verse poem) in grammar was Imam Ibn Mu'ti. He said, may Allah have mercy on him, in the introduction of his Alfiyah (1): And this drove truthful brothers of mine to... Demand from me that I organize. A concise poem (Urjuzah) in grammar... Its count is a thousand, free from stuffing. Because of their knowledge that memorizing poetry... Is suitable for the intelligent and the slow of understanding. Then came Imam Ibn Malik after Ibn Mu'ti, and he organized his Alfiyah known as 'Al-Khulasah', and stated in its introduction that he followed Ibn Mu'ti's footsteps in the composition, as Ibn Mu'ti preceded him, and he is following his tradition. Ibn Malik said about his Alfiyah (2): And it requires satisfaction without anger... Surpassing the Alfiyah of Ibn Mu'ti. And he, by precedence, possesses preference... Deserving of my beautiful praise. And Allah decrees abundant gifts... For me and for him in the degrees of the Hereafter. The truth that must be said is that Ibn Malik's Alfiyah is more comprehensive and containing, while Ibn Mu'ti's Alfiyah is smoother and sweeter (3). Also, Al-Khulasah surpassed it by being organized on one meter, whereas Ibn Mu'ti's Alfiyah was on two meters: Rajaz and Sari'. Ibn Mu'ti said in the introduction of his Alfiyah (4): Especially the split meter of Rajaz... When built upon concise rhyming couplets. Or what resembles it from Sari'... With rhyming hemistichs like Tasri' (opening rhyme).

text: The Manuscript Copy. I relied in verification on a unique copy, though I spared no effort in searching for another copy, but I did not find anything useful in the indexes I returned to. The manuscript is from El Escorial, consisting of twenty-five plates; in each plate are two leaves. It is under number 1792, from leaf 66b to leaf 90b. 197. And if it is weak, prefer the erection (Nasb), and if ... it is prevented, then the necessity of erection is noted (1).
198. He said like "Ma laka wa Zaydan?" so look ... and erection if conjunction is not possible with an implied [verb].

The Exception (Al-Istithna')
199. What "Illa" (Except) excepted in positive speech is complete (3) by it ... so erect it, and following a negation or what resembles it.
200. Connected, follows 'La' if it precedes ... And 'La' if it is cut off; this is what (4) was selected.
201. And cancel "Illa" if you empty what is before it ... for what follows it, and if you compose the like of it.
202. And if repeated not for emphasis, then if ... you emptied or delayed, then erect them, you will be effortless.
203. Not one, so make for it what is required ... and the erection of all of them when advanced is accepted.
204. And except a genitive with "Ghayr" and "Siwa" ... parse like the excepted with "Illa" and "Suwa" (5).
205. With "La Yakunu", "Laysa": erection is mandatory ... likewise "Khala", "'Ada", or drag (make genitive) with them (6).
206. And after "Ma" erect, and genitive is rare ... and these two are verbs if they do not make genitive.
207. And like "Khala": "Hasha", "Hasha", "Hash", and "Ma" ... do not accompany it, and interpret whatever is delusional.

The State (Al-Hal)
208. The Hal is a surplus description understanding in ... a state, and the derivation possesses familiarity.
209. Like transition, and rigidity has occurred ... in a price (7) or interpreted (8), and it is believed.
foot_note:
1. i.e., Known.
2. With difficulty, the reading appeared from the manuscript, and in some words of this hemistich, we have written the closest reading.
3. i.e., Complete.
4. Relative pronoun.
5. One of the dialects of "Siwa".
6. They are then prepositions.
7. Like "I sold it a Mudd for such-and-such."
8. Like your saying: "Zayd attacked [like] a lion."

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
210. Indefiniteness of Hal, its wording is what is made indefinite ... and it came often as an indefinite Masdar.
211. And the owner of the Hal (Dhu al-Hal) is mostly not indefinite if ... you do not find what in the beginning was noted.
212. And its precedence over a genitive by a particle has disagreement (1) ... and it did not come from that to which it is added.
213. Except that which operates or part of that which ... it was added to, or like part of this.
214. And it is advanced erected by the verb or ... a conjugated description, and its precedence they refused.
215. Its operator which has the meaning of the verb settled ... not its particle like "Tilka", "Layta", and it is rare.
216. Like "Sa'id mustaqirran fi Halab" ... not "Dhaka busran atyabu minhu rutab" (2).
217. And enumerate the Hal for a single or number ... and it came for emphasis of an operator.
218. And a sentence it emphasized, so it was delayed ... and an operator, according to the most correct view, was implied.
219. And bring it as an adverb and a sentence containing ... a pronoun if its beginning is a present tense verb fixed.
220. Like its negation with "Ma" and "La" and forbidden is ... the Waw, and intend a subject in what is delusional.
221. Like the past tense before "Aw" or "Illa" followed ... and connect other than this sentence with the Waw.
222. Or a pronoun and with both, and deleted is ... the operator of Hal, and obligatorily it is familiar.
foot_note:
1. Ibn Malik permitted it following Ibn Kaysan, Ibn Burhan, Abu Ali Al-Farisi, and Ibn Jinni. See: Idah al-Shi'r by Abu Ali 1/481, Sharh al-Umdah 1/429, Sharh al-Tashil 2/337, and Ham' al-Hawami' 2/306.
2. This is one of the most famous sayings teeming in grammar books. Al-Suyuti devoted a separate treatise to this issue called "Tuhfat al-Nujaba fi Qawlihim: Hadha Busran Atyabu Minhu Rutaban" and included it in his great book Al-Ashbah wa Al-Naza'ir. Ibn Tulun did likewise in his book "Al-Masa'il Al-Mulaqqabat fi Ilm Al-Nahw" where he called it "The Busriyyah Issue". See: Al-Ashbah wa Al-Naza'ir 4/652, Al-Masa'il Al-Mulaqqabat 61, and Sharh Al-Radi 'ala Al-Kafiyah 2/34.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
The Distinction (At-Tamyiz)
223. A noun with the meaning of "Min" (from), clarifying, indefinite ... erected as Tamyiz by what interpreted it.
224. Of number, measure, weight, and possessed of (1) ... area, and everything resembling this (2).
225. And after other than number, make genitive if you add ... and erection after what is added is known.
226. If it does not suffice instead of what is added to it ... like the agent in meaning, by the noun he preferred it.
227. And after an exclamation (Ta'ajjub), distinguish ... and dragging with "Min" (3) possessing number (4) "Ma" (5) was permitted.
228. Like an agent converted from an agent or ... object or added (6), and the other they saw.
229. And the operator of Tamyiz inevitably preceded ... and its precedence over the conjugated (7) the Sheikh (8) selected.

The Prepositions (Huruf Al-Jarr)
230. Here are the prepositions, start with "Min" ... partition and clarify, and with negation increase.
231. And its like in an indefinite (9), and as a substitute ... understood like the Ba, and for the end "Ila".
232. "Hatta" and Lam, and for possession this (10) follows ... and its like, and increase and transgress, give reason.
foot_note:
1. Meaning owner of.
2. Demonstrative.
3. "Min" in meaning is an agent.
4. "Dha" is an object for the Masdar "Jarr".
5. "Ma" here is a negation particle.
6. Deletion of Tanween from "Mudaf" is a necessity, similar to "Bashashata" from the saying: Taghayyara kullu dhi ta'min wa lawnin * Wa qalla bashashata al-wajhu al-malihu. See: Al-Insaf 2/545 and Ham' al-Hawami' 3/276.
7. Meaning the operator of the Tamyiz, the conjugated verb, precedes it.
8. i.e., Ibn Malik. See: Al-Alfiyyah p. 115 verse 363.
9. Meaning the indefinite noun.
10. i.e., The Lam.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
233. With "Fi" and Ba take adverbiality and causality ... and like "Ma'a" and "Min" and "'An" the Ba comes.
234. And transgress, compensate, attach, seek help with this ... with "'An" transgression, "'Ala" (1), "Ba'da" (2) take.
235. "'Ala" for elevation and the meaning of "'An" and "Fi" ... and the Kaf liken, increase, and give reason, you will follow.
236. And it may come as a noun like "'Ala" and "'An", and dragged ... this with a particle and added settled.
237. And "Mudh" and "Mundhu", and for time these two drag ... like "Min" in the past, and like "Fi" in what is present.
238. And two nouns if the sentence follows them or ... nominative, and dragging other than an apparent noun they refused.
239. Like the Kaf: Hatta, the Waw, Rubba, the Ta. And Rubb ... specified indefinite, and Ta-Allahi and Rabb.
240. And the increase of "Ma" in "Min" and "'An" does not restrain ... and Ba, and mostly "Rubba" and Kaf are restrained.
241. And "Rubba" was implied so it dragged after "Bal" ... and the Waw, Fa, and without "Rubba" that is rare.

The Genitive Construction (Al-Idafah)
242. Tanween or a Nun for declension delete ... from what you add, and the second make genitive and intend "Fi".
243. Or Lam or "Min", and specify the first or ... define with the second; the indefinite absolutely they followed.
244. In the first resembling "Yaf'alu" the description ... and name this verbal, lightened (3).
245. And that is semantic and pure (4) ... and the connection of "Al" with this added we accept.
foot_note:
1. Meaning it comes with the meaning of "'Ala" (on), like the poet's saying: Lah ibnu 'ammika la afdalta fi hasabin * 'anni wa la anta dayyani fatakhzuni. See: Huruf al-Ma'ani wa al-Sifat by Al-Zajjaji 79, Idah al-Shi'r by Abu Ali Al-Farisi 1/41, Amali Ibn al-Shajari 2/195, and Sharh al-Tashil 3/159.
2. Meaning it comes with the meaning of "Ba'da" (after), like His saying: "Latarkabunna tabaqan 'an tabaq". See: Ma'ani al-Qur'an by Al-Farra 3/251, Al-Tibyan by Al-Ukbari 2/1279, Tawjih al-Luma' 529, Sharh al-Kafiyah al-Shafiyah 2/809, and Al-Tadhyil wa al-Takmil 11/225.
3. Which is where the Mudaf is a description resembling "Yaf'alu". See: Sharh Ibn al-Nazim 275 and Sharh al-Muradi 2/786.
4. Reference to the first section where the Idafah is on the meaning of the preposition. See: Sharh Ibn Aqil 3/45 and Al-Maqasid Al-Shafiyah 4/35.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
246. If it is plural or dual or connected ... to the second or what worked the genitive in it.
247. Masculinity gain the first if, were it lost ... it would not be breached (1), and do not add to the united.
248. In meaning (2), and interpret (3), and added forever ... names (4), and some of them with a wording singular.
249. And some of them prevent from being added to an apparent noun ... like "Wahda", "Labba" and "Dawalay" and worthy.
250. And compel the sentence to "Haythu" and "Idh" ... and if "Idh" takes Tanween it is singular, and what is like these.
251. In meaning like this add, and this build and parse ... and before a verb built (past), the building was chosen.
252. And before a declinable and a subject, anomalous (5) ... is its declension, and compel the verb to "Idha".
253. For two generally not separated: "Kila" ... "Kilta", and for the individual defined then no.
254. "Ayy" add (6) unless repeated or intended ... parts, and for the relative pronoun generally believe.
255. And the Hal and the description for an indefinite absolutely ... and its interrogation and condition were released.
256. And drag the follower of "Lad" and "Ma'" then minimize ... and open or break for a sukun that followed.
257. And "Ghayr" join (with Damma) necessarily its building ... if you do not add it intending its meaning.
258. Like: Qablu, Hasbu, Awwalu, Duna, Wara ... 'Alu, and if you make indefinite then erect (7) and drag.
foot_note:
1. In the manuscript "Lam Yanjazim", and perhaps the correct is what we established.
2. Because a thing is not added to itself. See: Al-Muqtadab 3/241, Sharh Al-Sirafi 1/445, and Al-Ta'liqah by Al-Farisi 1/142.
3. Meaning you interpret everything appearing to be added to itself.
4. Shortened from "Asma'" out of necessity.
5. i.e., "Shaddha", and this is the school of the Basrans, while the Kufans permitted its building and Ibn Malik followed them, so he said in the Alfiyyah: "Wa min bana falan yufannada". See: Al-Alfiyyah p. 119 verse 402 and Al-Bahjah Al-Mardiyyah 320.
6. Perhaps it is "Adif" (Imperative).
7. In the manuscript "Insib" without the Fa, and without it the meter is disturbed.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
259. And the Mudaf (added) is deleted, so the follower for this ... succeeds in the ruling, or drag it (genitive) if.
260. The deleted resembles what is conjoined after ... and the first remains if the second is deleted.
261. In its state on condition of conjunction following ... you added it to the like of the follower of the first.
262. An object or adverb, permit that they separate ... the operator, the Mudaf, from a second following.
263. Likewise the oath with "Imma" is forgiven ... and the adjective and the call and the alien are rare.

The Added to the Yaa of the Speaker
264. The end of this with the Yaa break, and say excepted is ... the one with a defect, the plural, and the dual.
265. So the Yaa and the Waw with this Yaa are assimilated (1) ... and an Alif not in Hudhayl (2) was safe.
266. I said (3): And the names: Abi, Akhi, Hani ... Fi, Hami, and Dhi, were not improved (4).

Operation of the Masdar (Verbal Noun)
267. Like its verb is the Masdar if it takes the place ... of a verb and "An" or "Ma", added or with "Al".
268. Or not, and it is not implied, and complete ... nominative and accusative after dragging what followed.
269. And the dragged follows in wording or place (5) ... and for the Noun of Masdar, i.e., the Mimic, is an operation.
foot_note:
1. "Iddaghama" is the school of the Basrans, "Adghama" is the school of the Kufans. See: Al-Kitab 4/431, Sharh Al-Mufassal 5/512, Sharh Al-Kafiyah Al-Shafiyah 4/2175, and Al-Tashil 320.
2. See: Ma'ani Al-Qur'an by Al-Zajjaj 3/354, Al-Lamat 98, I'rab Al-Qur'an by Al-Nahhas 1/48, Sharh Al-Sirafi 4/162, and Al-Masa'il Al-Askariyyat 85.
3. Al-Suyuti means himself. See: Al-Bahjah Al-Mardiyyah 337.
4. Al-Farra permitted it. See: Al-Bahjah Al-Mardiyyah 337.
5. Meaning: It follows on its wording so it is genitive, or it follows on its place so it is accusative or nominative.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
Operation of the Active Participle (Ism Al-Fa'il)
270. Like its verb is the active participle if it is isolated ... from the past and for a negation followed.
271. Or an interrogative particle or came as an attribute ... or a predicate or attribute of what has deleted.
272. And if it is the connection of "Al", then absolutely ... "Fa'al" or "Mif'al" like the one preceding.
273. Likewise "Fa'ul" and "Fa'il" and "Fa'il" ... and whatever is other than the singular like it operates.
274. And an operator erects or lowers (genitive) what ... follows, and the erection of other than it is mandatory.
275. And the dragged follows in wording or place ... and for the Passive Participle (Ism Maf'ul) like it is an operation.
276. With its condition and ruling, no exception ... or add to the one with elevation in meaning (1).

Structures of Masdars
277. "Fa'l" for the one with three transitive (2), "Fa'al" ... like "Farah" for the intransitive on "Fa'ila".
278. And "Fa'ala" the intransitive possessed of "Fu'ul" ... like "Ghada" (3) and this is not encompassing.
279. Rather possessed of refusal, for it is "Fi'al" (4) ... and the ailment and the sound, for it is "Fu'al" (5).
280. And "Fa'alan" for it possesses volatility (6) ... for movement, and the sound "Fa'il" was chosen (7).
281. "Fu'ulah", "Fa'alah" for "Fa'ula" (8) ... and what for this differed, take what was transmitted.
282. And other than the one with three is measured ... its Masdar like "Quddisa al-Taqdisu".
283. And "Zakkihi Tazkiyatan" and "Ajmila ... Ijmala man tajammulan tajammala".
284. And "Ista'idh Isti'adhatan" then "Aqim ... Iqamatan", and mostly this Ta is required.
foot_note:
1. Thus it is permissible to add the passive participle to its nominative, and it is not permissible to add the active participle to its nominative.
2. Like: Daraba Darban.
3. Its Masdar is Ghuduww.
4. Like: Aba Iba'an.
5. Like: Sa'ala Su'alan.
6. Like: Dara Dawaranan.
7. Like: Sarakha Surakhan.
8. Like: Sahula Suhulah, and Jazula Jazalah.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
285. And extend and open following a seal (end) and break ... the third of the one with Hamza, you will find the Masdar.
286. And the fourth join (Damma) in "Tafa'lala" ... "Fi'lal" (1) or "Fa'lalah" for "Fa'lala".
287. And "Fa'ala": "Al-Fi'al" and "Al-Mufa'alah" ... and "Fa'lah" for a specific instance similar.
288. And "Fi'lah" for a specific mode, and other than the ... three with the Ta, and the mode cast away (2).

Structures of Active Participles and Attributes Resembling Them
289. Like "Fa'il" is the active participle of the triliteral ... for "Fa'ila" of colors and events.
290. So "Af'al" and "Fa'lan" possessed of fullness (3) ... and what is for accidents, formulate it "Fa'ila" (4).
291. And not "Fa'ultu" for it has "Fa'il" (5) ... and "Al-Fa'l" (6) take and "Af'al" (7) is rare.
292. And "Af'al" (8), and other than "Fa'il" was described ... "Fa'al" opened with it like the description of "'Aff" (9).
293. And other than the one with three is like the present tense ... with joining of the first and breaking the fourth.
294. And if you open, then it is a passive participle, and the ... one with three on the weight of Maf'ul take.
295. And represented by transmission on its behalf "Fi'l" (10) and "Fa'al" (11) ... "Fa'il" (12) in their meaning except operation.

The Attribute Resembling the Active Participle (Al-Sifah Al-Mushabbahah)
296. The Attribute Resembling the Active Participle ... is that which dragging its agent was deemed good.
297. From an intransitive for a present, and it operates ... like a participle, and in conditions it is placed.
foot_note:
1. In the manuscript "Fa'al", and the correction is from the Alfiyyah. See: Alfiyyah Ibn Malik p. 125 verse 453.
2. For it is anomalous in other than the triliteral.
3. Like Ahmar (Red) and Shab'an (Full).
4. Like Ashir.
5. Like Jamil.
6. Like Dakhm.
7. Like Batal.
8. Like Akhtab.
9. So he is 'Afif.
10. Like Dhibh.
11. Like Qabd meaning Maqbud.
12. Like Kahil.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
298. And the implied described connect with the operated ... and its precedence to it for its branch (1) is prohibited.
299. So raise and drag and erect with it with "Al" and no ... possessor of "Al" and possessor of addition and what is devoid.
300. And do not drag with "Al" a name from "Al" devoid ... and from addition to what followed it.

The Wonder (Al-Ta'ajjub)
301. "Af'il" and "Ma Af'ala" take for wonder ... and following this (2) erect, and that (3) drag with Ba.
302. And its deletion (4) permit if the meaning is known ... and for the rigidity of the two forms, it is committed.
303. And the formulation from a triliteral, conjugated ... accepting excess, possessed of completeness, what (5) is negated.
304. Whose description is not "Af'ala" (6), or like "Yutta'ad" ... and lacking, replace it: "Ashdid" or "Ashadd".
305. Its Masdar after "Ashadda" erect, and drag ... with Ba after "Ashdid", and other than this is rare (7).
306. And the verb of this chapter advance it, and connect ... its operated, and separation by the adverb was transmitted (8).

Ni'ma and Bi'sa and What Runs in Their Course
307. Two verbs: "Ni'ma", "Bi'sa", rigid ... for two nouns defined, so they are raisers (nominative).
308. Or an implied [noun] interpreted by a distinguisher (Tamyiz) ... and its combination with an agent is permitted.
foot_note:
1. Because it is a branch of the Active Participle, so it is weak.
2. "Ma Af'ala".
3. "Af'il".
4. i.e., deletion of the Ba and what is after it, similar to His saying: "Asmi' bihim wa Absir".
5. "Ma" here is negative.
6. i.e., its description is not on Af'al.
7. Like their saying: "Ma adhra'aha".
8. Like the saying of Al-Abbas bin Mirdas: Wa qala nabiyyu al-muslimina taqaddamu * wa ahbib ilayna an takuna al-muqaddama. See: Sharh al-Tashil 3/35, Al-Lamhah fi Sharh al-Mulhah 1/523, and Al-Maqasid Al-Nahwiyyah 3/1480.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
309. And what is in "Bi'sa ma ishtaraw" (1) is a distinguisher (2) ... and Sibawayh (3) is an agent and they distinguished.
310. And afterwards came the specific [noun] not with a pointer ... as a subject or predicate for an implied.
311. Like "Bi'sa": "Sa'a", and like "Ni'ma": "Fa'ula" ... from the triliteral, and "Habbadha" make.
312. Its agent "Dha", and with "La" say blameworthy ... and follow "Dha" its specific whatever.
313. And keep "Dha" and what is other than it raise with "Habba" ... or drag with Ba, and from it the joining (Damma) of the Ha dominated.

The Elative (Af'al al-Tafdil)
314. Af'al for preference is like the wonder (4) ... in formulation and prevention and connection of what was refused.
315. And if stripped connect with "Min" and make indefinite ... unify as added to the indefinite.
316. And the follower of "Al" matches, and if added to ... a known and the meaning of "Min" you discarded, then like this.
317. And if you intended, then with two faces speak ... and if for "Min" an interrogative with it followed.
318. Advance them, and its raising of the apparent is rare (5) ... and common if it occupied the place of the verb.
319. Like "Ma ra'aytu rajulan ahsana fi ... 'aynayhi kuhlun minhu fi 'ayni al-safi".

The Adjective (Al-Na't)
320. Follows in declension the first names ... Adjective and Emphasis and Conjunction and Substitute.
321. So the adjective is a follower completing (6) what it described ... either for it or its causal it was fixed.
322. So let it run like the described in indefiniteness and in ... definition and it is like a verb if followed.
foot_note:
1. Al-Baqarah 90.
2. See: Al-Tibyan by Al-Ukbari 1/91, Al-Bahr Al-Muhit 1/472, and Al-Durr Al-Masun 1/507.
3. See: Al-Kitab 3/155.
4. Their rulings are from one chapter. See: Al-Ashbah wa Al-Naza'ir 4/477.
5. This is called the Kuhl Issue.
6. Permissible with Tanween and without Tanween with addition of what is after it to it.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
323. Masculine, singular, and branch, and describe ... with the description and the resembling it like "Dhi" (1) and "Ti" (2).
324. And a sentence with a connector not for request ... indefinite, and a Masdar and it was mandatory.
325. Its masculinity and singularity, and the differing ... from the description of other than the singular distinguish inclined.
326. And the description of two operated by unique operation ... and meaning follow it like descriptions following.
327. Needful and if without them it is distinguished ... or some of them, allow following and cutting.
328. Nominative and accusative by that which deletion adhered ... and they deleted a description and a described known (3).

The Emphasis (Al-Tawkid)
329. With "Al-Nafs" (Self) emphasize names and "Al-'Ayn" (Eye/Same) ... with a pronoun matching, and gather these two.
330. With "Af'ul" if they followed the dual ... and "Kull" (All) mention if inclusion is meant.
331. "Kilta", "Jami'an" and "Kila" with a pronoun ... and "Fa'ilan" from "'Amma" with the Ta mention (4).
332. And after "Kull" come with "Ajma'", "Juma'" ... "Jam'a'", "Ajma'in" or leave all.
333. And it is what I see, for the Eloquent One said (5): ... "Sallu Julusan Ajma'un" (Pray sitting all together) in the Sahih (6).
334. And do not emphasize an indefinite unless it benefits (7) ... and in the dual the formulation of "Ajma'" is lost.
335. And if you emphasize a nominative connected pronoun ... with "Al-Nafs" and "Al-'Ayn" then after the disconnected.
336. Not with other than these two, and the verbal ... is repeated, and that is semantic (8).
foot_note:
1. Meaning Owner (Sahib).
2. Demonstrative noun.
3. Deletion of the described is frequent, and deletion of the description is rare.
4. He did not explicitly state "'Ammah" because it leads to the meeting of two still letters in the stuffing of the verse, and this is not permissible.
5. He means the Prophet, peace be upon him.
6. See: Sahih Al-Bukhari 1/139 and Sahih Muslim 1/309.
7. The issue is disputed between the two schools. See: Al-Insaf 2/369, Sharh Al-Tashil 3/296, and Al-Maqasid Al-Shafiyah 5/16.
8. He refers by "that" to what passed of Al-Nafs, Al-'Ayn, Kila, Kilta, etc.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
337. And if you repeat a relative pronoun, then the one which ... you connected with, and the particle likewise.
338. Other than an answer, and with a pronoun separated ... for the nominative emphasize every connected pronoun.

The Explanatory Apposition ('Atf Al-Bayan)
339. 'Atf Al-Bayan is a follower to what comes ... clarifying like an adjective in agreement with the first.
340. Come with them both defined or indefinite ... and as a substitute it is seen except in two.
341. Like "Al-Tariki Al-Bakriyyi Bishrin" (1) for example ... and "Ya Ghulamu Ya'mura", and it was problematic (2).

The Conjunction ('Atf Al-Nasaq)
342. Conjoin with Waw, Fa and "Thumma" coordinated ... "Hatta", "Am", "Aw" and these followed absolutely.
343. And "Bal" and "Lakin", "La" verbally, and conjoin ... accompanying or preceding or following.
344. With the Waw with possessor of partnership like "Istaffa" (3) ... and specify with order and speed the Fa.
345. And conjunction of other than a connection to the connection ... and "Thumma" for order and separation (4) make it.
346. A part and an end with "Hatta" and "Am" that is ... after a Hamza equating or like "Ay".
347. And it is like "Bal" if it is empty, and doubt and allow ... with "Aw" and give choice, divide, be vague, and you will be correct.
foot_note:
1. Reference to the saying of Al-Murrar Al-Asadi from the Wafir meter: Ana Ibn Al-Tariki Al-Bakriyyi Bishr * 'Alayhi al-tayru tarqubuhu wuqu'an. The witness in it is his saying "Bishr" for it is 'Atf Bayan not a substitute from "Al-Bakri" because the substitute is on the intention of repeating the operator so it would be "Al-Tariki Bishr" and this is not permissible because it necessitates adding the one with "Al" to one devoid of it, and that is not permissible, so 'Atf Bayan was determined. See: Al-Kitab 1/182, Al-Usul 1/135, Sharh Al-Kafiyah Al-Shafiyah 3/1196, Sharh Ibn Aqil 3/222, Ham' al-Hawami' 3/161, and Khizanat Al-Adab 4/284.
2. The one who found it problematic against Ibn Malik is Ibn Hisham in his footnote on Al-Tashil. See: Al-Bahjah Al-Mardiyyah 404.
3. The Alif is for duality.
4. Meaning with a delay, and every delay is according to it.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
348. Like "Bal" and like the Waw if confusion is negated ... and like "Aw": "Imma" and this did not conjoin.
349. A call affirmatively and a command do not follow ... a negation and prohibition "Bal" and "Lakin" and transmit.
350. With "Bal" for a second the ruling of a first at ... a command and positive, and "Laysa" make good.
351. Conjunction with it in meaning only and it is the most worthy ... for Al-Shafi'i, our Imam, spoke with it (1).
352. And conjoin to a connected nominative pronoun ... with a separator, and common is the conjunction of what separated.
353. And the genitive pronoun repeat if you conjoin ... to it a dragger (preposition), and leaving it was selected.
354. And the Fa is deleted and a follower if safe ... and the Waw likewise, and specification (2) was noted.
355. By conjunction of an operator you deleted and remained ... its operated, and deletion of a followed was selected.
356. If it appeared, and the conjunction in the verb was taken ... as long as it did not differ in time, so it was cast away (3).
357. And conjoin to a noun resembling a verb, a verb ... and its opposite, and the conjunction particle delete originally.

The Substitute (Al-Badal)
358. The substitute following without a particle (4), intended ... by the ruling, a part or matching appears.
359. Or possessed of inclusion or like the follower of "Bal" and this ... if intended as strike (Idrab) appeared (5), or cast away (6).
foot_note:
1. Imam Al-Shafi'i said in Kitab Al-Umm: "Li'anna al-taharati kullaha innama ju'ilat 'ala ma yazharu laysa 'ala al-ajwaf". See: Al-Umm 1/252 and Ham' al-Hawami' 3/218.
2. Meaning that it is specific to conjoining a deleted operator whose operated remained.
3. See: Al-Bahjah Al-Mardiyyah 419.
4. Caution against what is after Bal and Lakin. See: Sharh Al-Kafiyah Al-Shafiyah 3/1276.
5. Called Substitute of Strike (Badal al-Idrab) and Appearance (Bada'). See: Al-Bahjah Al-Mardiyyah 421.
6. Meaning if it was without intention, it is called Substitute of Error or Mistake. See: Al-Bahjah Al-Mardiyyah 422.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
360. By it the mistake, and apparent is not a substitute ... from an absent pronoun except what included.
361. Or came as encompassment and part (1), and say ... indicates what included Hamza this follows.
362. And the substitution of the verb from the verb appears ... and a sentence from a sentence and single (2).

The Call (Al-Nida')
363. Call a distant or likewise with "Ya", "Aya" ... "Haya" and "Ay", "A", "A" with Hamza near.
364. And "Ya" and "Wa" possessor of lamentation, "Ya" for confusion leave ... and deletion from lamentation and implied is prevented.
365. Like the succored (Mustaghath) and it is rare in names ... of pointing and the genus, not other than them.
366. And build on the nominative the unique (3) defined ... and intend with a built [noun] like the renewal of the adjective.
367. And the individual indefinite and the added erect and generalize ... the semi-added or "Jamila Al-Wajhi" (Beautiful of face) join (Damma).
368. And join and open from "A Zaydu bna 'Ali" ... and join if "Ibn" followed two proper nouns.
369. And add Tanween to the built out of necessity then erect ... or join, and the combination of "Ya" and "Al" was refused.
370. Except with "Allah" and the narrated sentences ... and the most common is "Allahumma". "Ya Allahumma" (4) is rare.
foot_note:
1. i.e., what conveyed a part.
2. Meaning a sentence substitutes a singular, like the saying of Ibn Abi Rabi'ah: Ila Allahi ashku bi-al-Madinati hajatan * wa bi-al-Shami ukhra kayfa yaltaqiyani. See: Sharh Al-Tashil 3/340, Sharh Al-Muradi 2/1050, and Mughni Al-Labib 273.
3. He means the singular.
4. Reference to the Rajaz of Abu Kharash: Inni idha ma hadithun alama * aqulu ya Allahumma ya Allahumma. The witness in it is his saying "Ya Allahumma" where the poet combined the particle of calling and the stressed Mim which comes as a substitute for it if deleted, and this is a necessity. See: Al-Fawa'id Al-Ajibah 29, Al-Muqtadab 4/242, Al-Insaf 1/279, Sharh Al-Kafiyah Al-Shafiyah 3/1307, and Al-Lamhah 2/798.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
Section
371. Erect an added without "Al" following (1) a Damma ... and raise or erect other than it, and make intended (2).
372. Like an independent in coordination and substitute ... and a coordinated with "Al" with two faces ascended.
373. Nominative (3), and "Ayyuha" specify inevitably with this ... "Al" raising and with the pointed to and "Alladhi".
374. And the description of a pointer to it lacked ... so raise, and "Sa'du Sa'da Al-Awsi" (4) the erection settled.
375. In the second, and the first join and open ... to the follower of the second it was added in the most correct view.

The Called Added to the Yaa
376. Added of Ya (5) correct called: 'Abdiya ... 'Abdi and 'Abdi, 'Abda, 'Abda delete for Ya.
377. And open or break Ya Ibna Umma, Ya Ibna 'Amm ... Abati, Ummati with this the two faces complete.

Names Adhering to the Call
378. Lu'man, Nawman, Fulu specify with the call ... and "Ya Khabathi" abuse of the female is regular (6).
379. From the triliteral, and "Fu'alu" was common ... for a male, and dragged in poetry "Fulu" (7).
foot_note:
1. Object for his saying "Erect".
2. It appears that his saying "Tu'ammu" is a parenthetical sentence, and the meaning: "And make like an independent in coordination..."
3. His saying: "Ascended a raising" means that the nominative is selected and chosen. See: Al-Alfiyyah p. 141 verse 587.
4. Reference to his saying from the Tawil meter: Aya Sa'du Sa'da Al-Awsi kun anta nasiran * wa ya Sa'du Sa'da Al-Khazrajina Al-Ghatarifi. The witness is: "Ya Sa'du Sa'da Al-Awsi" where he repeated the called one added so the erection of the second is mandatory and in the first are faces, and the intended two Sa'ds are Sa'd bin Mu'adh and Sa'd bin Ubadah. See: Hashiyat Ibn Hamdun 2/41, Al-Mujalasah wa Jawahir Al-Ilm 4/96, Al-Mustadrak 'ala Al-Sahihayn 3/283, Akam Al-Marjan 190, Hawatif Al-Jinan 36, and Al-Tamhid 24/105.
5. i.e., Yaa of the speaker.
6. In the manuscript: "Wa ittirada" and with the Waw the verse breaks.
7. He means: Tadillu minhu ibili bi-al-hawjali * tadafu'a al-shaybi wa lam tuqtali * fi lujjatin amsik fulana 'an fuli. The Rajaz is by Abu Al-Najm Al-Ijli from the famous poem starting: Al-Hamdu lillahi al-'aliyyi al-ajlali * al-wasi'i al-fadli al-wahubi al-mujzili. The witness in it is his saying "'an fuli" where he used it in other than the call and dragged it with the preposition. See: Al-Kitab 2/248, Al-Muqtadab 4/238, Al-Usul 1/349, and Sharh Al-Kafiyah Al-Shafiyah 3/1331.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
The Cry for Help (Al-Istighatha)
380. Lower (genitive) with a Lam a succored (Mustaghath) that came with ... an opening (Fatha) like in the conjoined with "Ya", and take.
381. In other than this the break (Kasra) (1), and for it append ... with an Alif likewise the possessor of wonder.

The Lamentation (Al-Nudba)
382. Like the one of the call is the one of lamentation, and the indefinite not ... lamented and the vague not what was connected.
383. And with an Alif connect it, and if followed by ... its end delete it like "Wa Musahu".
384. Tanween of what completed it likewise, and if ... delusional then from it the Alif flip not weak.
385. And the Ha increase in stopping permissibly, "Abdiya" ... "Abda" sang who in the call silenced Ya.

The Truncation (Al-Tarkhim)
386. Truncate by deleting the end the called ... feminine with the Ha or what increased.
387. Over three a proper noun not added ... and rare if supported, and its follower delete.
388. If it was soft still and extra ... completing four and upwards.
389. Like the end of the compound, and in the Waw differed ... and the Ya and not the opening, and if for what deleted.
390. You intended, keep its follower like what ... before and otherwise like if it were completed.
391. Like "Ya Thamu" and "Ya Thami" upon them ... "Muslimatu" the first in it obligate (2).
392. And permit the two faces in like "Maslamah" ... and acceptable of the call out of necessity truncate.
foot_note:
1. Object to his saying "Take" in the end of the previous verse.
2. Meaning that one must treat "Muslimah" upon truncation according to the dialect of the one who waits only, so you say: "Ya Muslima", and it is not permissible to run it on the dialect of the one who does not wait, so you do not say: "Ya Muslimu"; so that the masculine is not confused with the feminine, Muslim with Muslimah. See: Sharh Ibn Al-Nazim 427, Al-Maqasid Al-Shafiyah 5/454, and Sharh Al-Makudi 255.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
The Specialization (Al-Ikhtisas)
393. Specialization is like a call without "Ya" ... for "Ayy" or for "Al" coming following.

The Warning and Incitement (Al-Tahdhir wa Al-Ighra')
394. "Iyyaka wa al-Sharra" (Beware of evil) with warning erected ... concealed inevitably like "Iyyaka al-Ghadab" (Beware anger).
395. And other than "Iyya" the mention of its verb permit ... not the one of repetition and the one of conjunction valid.
396. "Iyyaka", "Iyyahu" is anomalous and likewise ... with other than "Iyya" what was incited with take.

Names of Verbs and Sounds (Asma' Al-Af'al wa Al-Aswat)
397. What substituted for a verb named the verb like "Sah" ... and what is with the meaning of "If'al" (1) is many like "Mah".
398. And rare is other than it like "Hayhata" and "Way" ... and from names of the verb "Ruwayda", "Balha", i.e.
399. If they erected, and as two Masdars they lowered (2) ... "'Alayka", "Dunaka", "Ilayka" turn (3).
400. And like a deputy for it operate advanced ... and if it takes Tanween then with its indefiniteness judge.
401. And its like is the narrated with it or addressed ... other than the one who reasons a sound like "Qaba" (4).

The Two Nuns of Emphasis
402. Emphasize with two Nuns severe and possessor (5) ... of lightness, a command and the present tense which.
403. Came as a request or a condition "Imma" followed ... or positive in an oath future.
404. And after "Ma" and "Lam" and "La" it did not preponderate ... and other than "Imma", and its end open.
foot_note:
1. He means the imperative verbal noun.
2. Meaning if they erected what follows them, they are verbal nouns, and if they dragged what follows them, they are Masdars, and what follows them is added to.
3. He means the meaning of "Ilayka" is turn away.
4. "Qab" is a narration of the sound of a sword strike. See: Al-Muhkam wa Al-Muhit Al-A'zam 6/143 and Taj Al-Arus 3/514.
5. i.e., owner, meaning: "possessed of lightness".

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
405. And vowelize it before a soft pronoun with what ... matches, and the pronoun its deletion commit.
406. Not an Alif, and the end of the verb the Alif ... Ya make if the Alif raises, and deleted.
407. If the Waw or the Ya raises, and vowelize ... these two and match, and the light does not follow.
408. For an Alif rather its sister and break, and with ... a Nun of females an Alif before gathered.
409. And delete a light one for a silent following ... and after other than the Fatha in pause ascended.
410. And return what for it in connection was deleted ... and after a Fatha flip Alif like "Qifa".

What Does Not Inflect (Ma La Yansarif)
411. Inflection is Tanween clarifying a meaning (1) ... so the Alif of femininity however appeared (2).
412. Prevents from inflection, and two extras in ... "Fa'lan" descriptive a Ta with its female was negated (3).
413. And an original description with "Af'al" prevented ... its femininity with the Ta, and the accidental (4) leave.
414. In the description and the name like "Al-Adham, Arba'i" ... two faces in like "Ajdal", and prevent.
415. A description with deviation ('Adl) like "Thulatha" and "Ukhar" ... "Mathna" and the weight of these two for the four settled.
416. And the plural possessor of the weight of "Mafa'il" and possessor ... of "Mafa'il", and the possessor of its defect take.
417. Nominative and genitive deletion of a Ya and add Tanween to it ... and prevent "Sarawil" for a resemblance in weight (5).
418. And the mixed proper noun or possessor of Alif ... and Nun of "Fa'lan" or the Ha prevent you fulfill.
419. And prevent a feminine with other than the Ha settled ... above three or like "Jawra" or "Saqar".
foot_note:
1. Which is that the noun is established in nominality, so it did not resemble the particle strongly to be built, nor the verb to be prevented from inflection.
2. The Alif in "'Anna" is for release (poetic license).
3. Ibn Malik has a poem for these words that came on Fa'lan Fa'lana in his book Nazm Al-Fawa'id. See: Nazm Al-Fawa'id 62.
4. Meaning accidental descriptiveness and nominality.
5. i.e., in the weight. See: Al-Alfiyyah p. 149 verse 660.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
420. Or its origin is masculine and if lost ... this and foreignness then its prevention find.
421. Like the foreign in placement and definition cited ... above three, or with the weight of the verb specified.
422. Or dominant, and a proper noun possessor of Alif ... of appending or possessor of deviation did not inflect.
423. And the proper noun of the female "Fa'ali" prevent likewise ... Tamim (1) and building with Kasra is the right of this.
424. And whatever definition influenced inflect ... indefinite, and from it the possessor of deficiency followed.
425. A defective plural, and out of necessity inflect ... the possessor of prevention and the inflected its prevention followed.

Declension of the Verb
426. Raise a present tense free from two operators of ... erection and jussive, and erect with "Lan" and "Kay".
427. And "An" except from after knowledge and that which ... from after supposition, raise and erect with this (2).
428. And with "Idhan" beginning, future ... connected or with an oath separated.
429. And after conjunction of this like "An" from after supposition ... and between "La" and a Lam commit the mention of "An".
430. And upon loss of "La" imply or show ... and after negation of "Kana" inevitably imply.
431. Like "Aw" if "Hatta" or "Illa" was valid (3) ... its place and after "Hatta" this became clear.
432. And following it the future erect and raise ... a present state and if you answer with a Waw like "Ma'in".
433. And the Fa of pure request or negation ... implied "An" and after other than negation.
434. If the Fa drops make jussive and after prohibition place ... "In" before "La" if it differs then jussive leave.
foot_note:
1. See: Al-Kitab 3/277 and Al-Muqtadab 3/49.
2. Because it is then lightened from the heavy and its subject is the pronoun of the affair and the sentence after it is the predicate.
3. Meaning that "An" must be implied after "Aw" if "Hatta" or "Illa" is valid in its place. See: Al-Kitab 3/47, Al-Muqtadab 2/28, Sharh Abyat Sibawayh 2/71, Sharh Ibn Al-Nazim 479, Sharh Al-Muradi 3/1246, and Al-Maqasid Al-Shafiyah 6/32.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
435. And the command other than "If'al" its answer make jussive ... and in an answer for hope erection obligate.
436. Or establish "An" and deletion of "An" and erection is anomalous ... in other than what passed and whoever analogized cast away.
437. And conjoin to a pure noun a verb with Fa ... or Waw or "Thumma" and erect and delete.

Factors of the Jussive (Jazm)
438. With "La" and Lam of request the verb make jussive ... and "Lam" and "Lamma", "In" and "Idhma", "Haythuma".
439. "Ayyan", "Ayna", "Man" and "Ayy", "Mahma" ... "Anna", "Mata", "Ma", following "Idhma" are names (1).
440. And "In" and its follower for two verbs made jussive ... the condition then the recompense this the answer name.
441. Two present tense verbs, two past verbs (2) or possessors of ... difference, and raise a recompense properly i.e.
442. From after a past and other than it whatever opened ... and couple with Fa inevitably an answer whatever was valid.
443. As a condition, likewise "Idha" and "Mahma" conjoined ... a verb to the recompense with Waw or with Fa.
444. Triplicate and the follower of Fa or Waw midst ... the two sentences erect it and make jussive only.
445. And what from the recompense and condition is known ... deleted, and what was delayed its answer deleted.
446. From an oath and the condition but if preceded ... a subject then the condition for mention is more entitled.
foot_note:
1. Idhma, Haythuma, Ayyan, Ayna, Man, Ayy, Mahma, Anna, Mata, Ma.
2. In this is a nice subtlety from Al-Suyuti, where he presented the present tense over the past, while Ibn Malik presented the past over the present, and presenting the present over the past is more appropriate because the present is more frequent. Ibn Jabir Al-Hawari said: "And his right was to present the two present tenses for their originality, but the poem ruled over him." But if we went along with Ibn Malik's school in necessity, there is no scope for what Ibn Malik fell into, and he could have avoided it. Al-Ghazzi said in his explanation on the Alfiyyah: And the most is the second so if he presented it * it would be better like if he organized it: Mudari'ayni thumma madiyyayni * tulfihima aw mutakhalifayni. See: Sharh Al-Kafiyah Al-Shafiyah 1/300, Shawahid Al-Tawdih wa Al-Tashih 160, Sharh Ibn Jabir Al-Hawari 4/145, Sharh Al-Ghazzi Verse 7024, and Khizanat Al-Adab 1/33.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
"Law" the Conditional
447. "Law" is a particle of condition in the past, and shifts ... to it a present tense following it, and rare.
448. Future in meaning, and with the verb it is specified ... and "Anna" a subject upon it 'Amr (1) cited (2).

"Amma" and "Lawla" and "Lawma"
449. "Amma" like "Mahma yakun min shay'in" and whatever ... verb follows this for a meaning known.
450. And Fa for its follower obligate and anomalous is ... in prose its deletion without a saying cast away.
451. "Lawla" and "Lawma" for prevention since existed ... a thing for the beginning commit and benefit.
452. With these two incitement and "Halla", "Alla" ... and with "Ala" offer, and they specified a verb.

Reporting with "Alladhi" and Alif and Lam
453. With "Alladhi" with its branches if you report ... a subject precede and come with the predicate.
454. And it is that which is said: Report about it ... and other than these two as a connection center it.
455. And the condition of what is reported about is that it accepted ... delay and a pronoun about it replaced (3).
456. Or a foreign [word] and with "Al" about some of this ... a verb advanced so report and mimic.
457. If the formulation of a connection from it for "Al" is valid ... and its raising an implied of other than it separated.
foot_note:
1. He means Sibawayh.
2. Sibawayh said: "And you say: Law annahu dhahibun lakana khayran lahu, so Anna is built on Law as it was built on Lawla, as if you said: Law dhaka". See: Al-Kitab 3/121.
3. i.e., permissibility of dispensing with it by a pronoun. See: Sharh Ibn Al-Nazim 515, Sharh Ibn Aqil 4/63, and Sharh Al-Makudi 300.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
The Number (Al-'Adad)
458. "Thalathah" to "'Ashrah" say for the male ... and its opposite (1) strip from the Ta, and dragged.
459. Its Tamyiz, and a plural of paucity appeared ... and "Mi'ah" to "Al-Alf" dragged what was single.
460. And rare is dragging (2) the plural, and mention in the male ... compound "Ahad" before "'Ashar".
461. In the opposite "Ihda 'Ashrata" or break ... a Shin (3), and take "Thalathah" for the other.
462. As passed, and "Al-'Ashr" then decree absolutely ... for it as for one preceded (4).
463. In the male "Ithna 'Ashara", the female "Ithnata ... 'Ashrata", and the first (5) declense, and other than Ta.
464. Is built on Fatha except "Thamani" ... for they permitted deletion with silence (Sukun).
465. With one "'Ishruna" is distinguished if ... made indefinite with compound or son of this.
466. Adding it, and formulate from "Ithnayn" to ... "'Asharah": "Fa'ilah" and "Fa'ila".
467. And add if you want with it some of that which ... from it you built it like "Thani ithnayn dha".
468. And if you want making the lesser like what ... is above then like the active participle operate and commit.
469. And if you wanted like "Thani ithnayn" ... compound then come with two compounds.
470. Or "Fa'il" add it to the compound ... or come with "Hadi 'Ashar" the succeeding.
471. And "Fa'il" before what is "'Ishrina" ... and the Waw take like "Al-Hadi wa Al-Tis'ina".
foot_note:
1. i.e., The feminine.
2. In the manuscript "Yujarru" and perhaps the correct is what we established.
3. Breaking the Shin is the dialect of Tamim. See: Ma'ani Al-Qur'an by Al-Akhfash 1/104, Sharh Al-Sirafi 2/9, and 'Ilal Al-Nahw 499.
4. With the Ta with the masculine, and without it with the feminine.
5. He means by the first "Ithna, Ithnata" for they are parsed with the inflection of the dual.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
"Kam" and "Ka'ayyin" (1) and "Kadha"
472. Distinguish like "'Ishrina": "Kam" if you interrogate ... and drag with "Min" an implied if "Kam" dragged.
473. Like "'Ashr" or like "Mi'ah" informing this ... and erect the two distinguishers of "Ka'ayyin" and "Kadha" (2).

The Quotation (Al-Hikayah)
474. What is for the indefinite with "Ayy" quote if ... you ask with it about it and in pause appeared (3).
475. And the Nun saturate and "Manani" if you make dual ... "Manayni", "Mantani", "Manah" the singular (4) appeared.
476. "Manatu" with "Manina" if plural is meant ... "Manuna" the Nun of what passed silence.
477. And if you connect then the wording of "Man" does not differ ... and quote with it proper nouns if they did not curve.

The Femininity (Al-Ta'nith)
478. Alif or Ta is the mark of femininity, in ... names intend a Ta, and with a pronoun know.
479. And the return in diminutive and reporting ... and Hal and adjective and with the pointer.
480. And "Mif'ala" does not follow "Fa'ul" originally ... "Mif'al", "Mif'il" and anomalous is what followed.
481. And mostly prevented from "Fa'il" ... following the described like "Al-Qatil".
482. And Alif of shortening and extending the first ... like "Marata" and "Uraba" and "Al-Tula".
483. And the weight of "Fa'la", "Summaha", "Hubara" ... "Dhikra", "Sibatra" of walking and "Al-Shuqqara".
foot_note:
1. Thus in the manuscript, and in Al-Ham': "As for 'Ka'ayyin' it is written with the Nun as a single saying". See: Ham' al-Hawami' 3/502.
2. Abu Hayyan has a book dedicated to "Kadha" called "Al-Shadha fi Mas'alat Kadha", explained by Ibn Hisham in a book he called "Fawh Al-Shadhal bi Mas'alat Kadha", quoted by Al-Suyuti in Al-Ashbah wa Al-Naza'ir. See: Al-Ashbah wa Al-Naza'ir: 4/281.
3. Thus in the manuscript and perhaps it is unbalanced.
4. Does not balance.

book_title: Al-Wafiyyah bi-Ikhtisar Al-Alfiyyah (Summary of Ibn Malik's Alfiyyah)
publisher: ‘Ilm’ Foundation for Heritage Revival and Digital Services
text:
484. And the weight of "Fi'ila", "Fu'ulla", "Faw'ala" ... and the weight of "Fu'ayla" and the weight of "Fa'lala".
485. And he increased in Kafiyah (1) other things ... possessing fame and other than these rare.
